questions.question: Which cloud service method utilizes only servers owned and operated by a third party?

explanation.Private: This cloud service uses internal servers owned by the company.
explanation.Public: This cloud service utilizes servers hosted by a third party.
explanation.Hybrid: This cloud service combines both internal and external servers.
explanation.Type II: This refers to a type of hypervisor, not a cloud service.
explanation.Type I: This also refers to a type of hypervisor, not a cloud service.

questions.question: Tom currently runs a cloud for his company on internal servers but needs some extra processing power to run a new application. What method of cloud service can he check out to leverage his existing cloud without needing to buy more internal servers?

explanation.Private: This is hosted internally, so Tom would need to buy additional servers.
explanation.Public: This is hosted externally, which wouldn't leverage his existing infrastructure.
explanation.Hybrid: This allows Tom to use both internal and external resources effectively.
explanation.Type I: This is a type of hypervisor, not a cloud service.
explanation.Type II: This is another type of hypervisor, not a cloud service.

questions.question: Sally is interested in developing her application in the cloud without having to worry about administering an operating system. What type of cloud service should she buy?

explanation.PaaS: Platform-as-a-Service allows developers to focus on coding without managing the OS.
explanation.IaaS: Infrastructure-as-a-Service provides hardware but requires OS management.
explanation.SaaS: Software-as-a-Service provides applications, not a development platform.
explanation.Hybrid cloud: This combines both private and public resources, requiring management.

questions.question: Which type of cloud service allows you to spin up your own operating systems on infrastructure provided by the cloud?

explanation.PaaS: This provides a platform but not the ability to manage OS installations.
explanation.Private cloud: This refers to an internal cloud setup.
explanation.IaaS: Infrastructure-as-a-Service allows you to create and manage your own operating systems.
explanation.SaaS: This provides software applications, not OS management.
explanation.Hybrid cloud: This combines resources but does not specifically allow OS management.

questions.question: Which type of hypervisor interfaces directly with the host system hardware?

explanation.Private: This refers to a cloud service model, not a hypervisor type.
explanation.Public: This also refers to a cloud service model.
explanation.Type II: This runs on top of a host operating system, not directly on hardware.
explanation.Type I: This hypervisor type runs directly on the hardware and manages resources.
explanation.Hybrid: This refers to a combination of cloud service types, not a hypervisor.

questions.question: Henry already has installed Red Hat Linux on his server but now needs to install virtual machines. What type of hypervisor package should he use?

explanation.Private: This refers to a cloud service model.
explanation.Public: This refers to a cloud service model.
explanation.Type II: This is correct; it runs on top of an existing OS.
explanation.Type I: This is incorrect; it runs directly on hardware.
explanation.Hybrid: This refers to a combination of service types.

questions.question: Which type of hypervisor template bundles all of the configuration files into a single file for distribution?

explanation.XML: This is a markup language, not a template format.
explanation.JSON: This is a data interchange format, not a template format.
explanation.OVA: This format packages all configuration files into a single file.
explanation.OVF: This format uses multiple files for configuration.
explanation.YAML: This is a data serialization language, not a template format.

questions.question: Fred wants to package his application so that it's guaranteed to run the same way no matter what Linux distribution his customers use. How can he do this?
options: Package the application as a container.
Package the application as a hypervisor.
Deploy the application to a private cloud.
Deploy the application as a virtual machine.
Bundle the application as a tar file and deploy it.
questions.answer: Package the application as a container.

This ensures that the application runs consistently across environments.
This is not a valid method for packaging applications.
explanation.Deploy the application to a private clou: This does not guarantee consistent execution across distributions.
explanation.Deploy the application as a virtual mach: This requires the same hypervisor on every customer machine.
explanation.Bundle the application as a tar file and: This does not ensure that all dependencies are met.

questions.question: What method should you use to easily move an application from a development environment to a production environment without having to duplicate the operating system?

explanation.Public cloud: This does not directly facilitate easy moves without OS duplication.
explanation.Private cloud: This requires managing the infrastructure, which complicates moves.
explanation.Type I hypervisor: This does not directly support application portability.
explanation.Type II hypervisor: This also does not facilitate easy moves.
explanation.Container: Containers encapsulate the application and its dependencies, enabling easy movement.

questions.question: Which Linux container package runs an engine as a process on the host operating system and provides a command-line interface to control containers?

explanation.Snap: This is a package management system for Linux.
explanation.Docker: This is the container platform that provides the command line for managing containers.
explanation.KVM: This is a kernel-based virtual machine and not a container platform.
explanation.XEN: This is a hypervisor for virtualization.
explanation.VirtualBox: This is a general-purpose virtualizer for running virtual machines.
